channel.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
channel.description:
**When a player gets lynched (not killed) they’re erased from the Timeline, changing the future.** For example; Pretend that, night 1, a doctor heals the JailKeeper, who jailed the Mafia Goon, and the Jailor was attacked by the Serial Killer. Therefore, no one dies because the doctor prevented the attack. Then, the next day the doctor is lynched. This renders null everything the Doctor previously did. Including the Heal... so the Jailor also dies. The Goon is shot the following night and the Serial Killer is lynched. This renders null both kills... so the Jailor is resurrected.
To make things easier; Only lynchées will be erased from the timeline. Lynchees cannot Be resurrected. Roles and factions are not flipped on death unless lynched. Evils *can* be resurrected. *No dead interaction. No dead chat.*
I thought this was an interesting idea, because anything can change with a single lynch.

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
except id say that a time traveler cannot cause time travel to happen
i.e. the time shenanigans boy cant send themselves back, only to send another person back for a chain reaction, and that someone else going back cant manipulate the time shenanigans boy in to sending someone else back (i.e. a steadfast rule; time manipulation can only affect up to two nights prior, even if you had multiple time machines and a plan, 2 nights before a machine is used is all said machine can affect)

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Magnus
item.description:
Okay.

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
they dont change their action later.
their whole body is going back in time, not just their consciousness.
they add another action to the resolving of night phase
so whatever action they do the night of time shenanigans,
the host takes it, and acts as if there were an extra player in the night-in-the-past, and that said player was doing that action, and then resolve that night phase again, using normal procedure, preferably something like https://wiki.mafiascum.net/index.php?title=Natural_Action_Resolution (i.e. not an action-list)
no arbitrary restrictions

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Magnus
item.description:
So they use their actions after everyone else?
Can this delay a death?

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
say the time shenanigans man has a 3-use ability to send someone 1 night back and a 1-use to send someone two.

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
its what those three posts were before you replied
semi-standard rolemadness fm, with 1 boy being time-shenanigans man.
have dead players submit actions even when dead, for a certain time after their passing until they can be confirmed dead, and dont let people redo actions, if an action they did would either not make logical sense (attempting to target someone who is now dead) or is not actually possible (they dont have a use left on it, perhaps.) then instead nothing happens

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
maybe that can be done later, but what im suggesting is relatively minor time shenanigans, and something like redacting a person (and thus removing their actions in the past as well, should someone go back) is a bit too complex to start out with

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
so basically, if the time shenanigans caused the person who was lynched one day to die the previous night, then the host doesnt redo the day/lynch, just no one is lynched that day

Read full topic

item.title: Idea - ButterFly effect
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.description:
i like the idea of semi-standard fm rolemadness, with one character that sends someone back in time for a night, and then the host goes back and redoes night results using like natural-action-deduction (or one of those things that uses logic to figure it out rather than an action order), adding in the new action, and then going from there;
you could treat not redoing the actions later as two timelines merging, so while some people’s physical status might have changed from others actions their own actions did not, and could not change.

Read full topic
